question_text: How does the geometry of triptycene moieties in PIM membranes influence gas transport properties for CO₂/CH₄ separation, specifically regarding chain rigidity, ultra-microporosity, and molecular sieving ability?
standard_answer: Triptycene-based PIM membranes exhibit enhanced CO₂/CH₄ separation performance due to their unique geometric structure, which increases chain rigidity and creates ultra-microporosity. The fused-ring and highly-rigid triptycene moiety, combined with restricted rotation of phenazine moieties and conformational barriers in the backbone, provides TPIM-1 and TPIM-2 with intra-chain rigidity higher than PIM-1 and PIM-PIs. This increased rigidity disrupts chain packing more effectively, creating narrower pore size distributions and higher ultra-microporosity. The high surface area and ultra-microporosity of TPIM-1 are attributed to chain packing disruption caused by the triptycene core block and the large sizes of bridgehead substituents. The molecular sieving ability of triptycene-based PIMs is directly ascribed to this combination of chain rigidity and ultra-microporosity, which preferentially allows smaller CO₂ molecules to diffuse while hindering larger CH₄ molecules. This geometric optimization results in TPIM-1 showing CO₂ permeability of 1545 Barrer with enhanced selectivity compared to other PIM structures, demonstrating how moiety geometry directly controls the balance between diffusivity and solubility mechanisms for superior gas separation performance.
